results.title: Golden Gate
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is America”.
San Francisco is the subject of this United States Travel Service program, from the series, “This Is America”. It is a colourful and breezy look at the Californian city which attracts so many tourists annually. Highlights include Fisherman’s Wharf, the Golden Gate Bridge, Chinatown and Alcatraz

results.title: Golden braid
results.creator_credit: Paul Cox, Paul Ammitzboll, Santhana Naidu, Film Victoria and Illumination Films (AU)
results.brief_description: Bernard is an eccentric clockmaker; Terese is the sultry young Salvation Army worker with whom he is having an affair. Obsessed by the past, he finds a golden braid in an 18th century cabinet and immerses himself in the pursuit of a fantasy. It is up to Terese to lure him away from the ghost of the past, reignite their passion and seduce him back to reality.

results.title: Golden beginnings
results.brief_description: Traces the development of Ballarat from the first gold strike in 1851 and the mining period that followed, through its early industrial growth to its present position as a prosperous industrial city. Narrated by John Collins. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
results.description: Traces the development of Ballarat from the first gold strike in 1851 and the mining period that followed, through its early industrial growth to its present position as a prosperous industrial city. Narrated by John Collins. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Gold diggers' ballad: the watercolours of S.T.Gill (1818-80)
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: The famous watercolours by S. T. Gill reflect the optimism and feeling or spirit of the goldrushes. The gold diggers’ expressive faces and activities show the tremendous fever and hunger after gold in the 1850’s in Victoria. The paintings are presented with a background of Australian ballads with guitar accompaniment.

results.title: Going to blazes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
A survey of fire-fighting services in Britain. Over 35,000 fire-fighters, some full-time, some part-time keep constant watch for outbreaks of fire in town or country. Shows something of life on and off duty with units of the Glasgow and London fire services; visits a Fire Research Station where experts study the cause and effect of fire. Narrated by Tim Turner.

results.title: Going through customs
results.creator_credit: Rolly Desmarais, ONF | NFB and Rolly Productions
results.brief_description: Every day, streams of people, goods and commodities of all descriptions come into Canada at border crossings along the 6 500 km Canada-U.S. border, and via airports and seaports. Keeping the traffic moving expeditiously, at the same time ensuring that Canadian government regulations concerning immigration, customs and excise, health, and agriculture are observed, is the job of the Customs Officer. This is a colorful, coast-to-coast look at the variety that enters into his day.

results.title: Going on to further study (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A humorous examination of the advantages and importance of further education to; a)levels of skill needed to match those of other countries and ; b)our children will have more time to devote to things other than earning a living. Further education gives them a better understanding of their place in the world and of themselves.

results.title: Going metric
results.brief_description: Examines practical details of changing to the metric system in a precision engineering company. Discusses replacement and adaptation problems in machinery, tools and supplies, the drawing office and staff training.

results.title: Going home [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Omar Al-Qattan, Cafe Productions and Sindibad Films
results.brief_description: A Palestinian/UK co-production produced and directed by Palestinian born Omar Al-Qattan about the memories of a former British soldier, Major Derek Cooper, during the final days of the British abandonment of the Palestinian Arabs in their struggle against the occupying Jewish militia in Jaffa in Palestine in 1948. In the director’s words “Going Home is an attempt to pose the question of memory - whether Arab, Jewish or British - as a central issue in any dialogue which is to lead to a lasting and just peace in the region.” Through Major Cooper’s reminiscings and personal stories, the viewer is given an insight into the historical background of the Jewish Arab conflict from the years of British rule and involvement through to the Jewish immigration after WWII, the UN Partition Plan of 1947/48, the setting up of the State of Israel, the expulsion and dispossession of over three quarter million Palestinian Arabs, the battle of Jaffa and the subsequent establishment of refugee camps along the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. Also provides the Jewish and Palestinian perspectives through interviews with academics and historians, with Jews who fought with the Jewish underground militias in the battle for Jaffa and with Palestinian refugees living in the camps. Contains stills, archival and newsreel footage. In Arabic and English with English subtitles.

results.title: Gogodala: a cultural revival
results.brief_description: An edited version of a film by Chris Owen which examines the impact of Christianity upon the Gogodala Tribes of Western Papua New Guinea. It caused the cessation of major ceremonies and rituals, the interruption of the tribal patterns of life, and the stagnation of their art and expression. However, in 1973, with the aid of the National Cultural Council, attempts have been made towards a cultural revival, which though sometimes influenced by western and other tribal practices, has given the Gogodala a renewed sense of identity.
